[[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] (RB) | overall_record = 69–58 (college)
8–11 (junior college) | bowl_record = 2–3 | tournament_record = | CFbDWID = 1394 | championships = | awards = [[Kansas Jayhawk Community College Conference|KJCCC]] Coach of the Year (1982) | coaching_records = | CFBHOF_year = | CFBHOF_id = }} '''Steve Logan''' (born February 3, 1953) is an [[American football]] coach. Most recently, he served as the [[running backs coach]] for the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL), a position he held from 2009 to 2011. Logan was the head football coach at [[East Carolina University]] from 1992 to 2002, compiling a record of 69–58. ==Early life== Logan was born in [[Lawton, Oklahoma]] and grew up in [[Broken Arrow, Oklahoma]].{{cite book |title=2011 NFL Record and Fact Book |url=http://nflmedia.com/2011_NFL_Record_&_Fact_Book.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=May 15, 2012 |publisher=[[National Football League]] |page=222}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1992/01/12/sports/sports-people-college-football-coach-for-e-carolina.html |title=Coach for East Carolina |author=Associated Press |date=January 12, 1992 |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=December 14, 2011}} He attended Broken Arrow High School where he lettered in football, basketball and track.{{cite web |url=http://www.ba.k12.ok.us/vnews/display.v/SEC/Athletics%20Department|Hall%20of%20Fame |title=Hall of Fame |publisher=[[Broken Arrow Public Schools]] |accessdate=December 18, 2011}} Logan was recruited by coach [[Harold Elliott|Bud Elliott]] to play football at [[Emporia State University]], a [[Division II (NCAA)|Division II]] school in [[Emporia, Kansas]].{{cite web |url=http://www.newspaperarchive.com/SiteMap/FreePdfPreview.aspx?img=113168405 |title=Elliott Announces Signing of Three Football Prospects |date=July 1, 1971 |publisher=[[Emporia Gazette]] |accessdate=December 18, 2011}} He played one season as a [[defensive back]] for the Hornets before deciding to end his playing career.{{cite book |last=Ritenour |first=William M. |year=2008 |title=Pirate Odyssey, a 75 Year History of East Carolina Football Volume 2 |publisher=[[iUniverse]] |location=[[Bloomington, Indiana]] |page=246 |isbn=978-0-595-46858-4 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=LsKxs8hVmUoC |accessdate=December 18, 2011}} Logan then transferred to the [[University of Tulsa]], planning to pursue a career in college teaching.{{cite web |url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/news/article.aspx?no=subj&articleid=538861 |title=Tulsa Notepad |last=Trammel |first=Jimmie |date=November 8, 1995 |work=[[Tulsa World]] |accessdate=December 12, 2011}} After graduating in 1975, he was hired as a [[physical education]] teacher and assistant football coach at [[Union Public Schools|Union High School]] in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]]. ==Coaching career== ===Early positions=== His first collegiate coaching position was a one-year stint as [[tight ends coach]] at [[Oklahoma State University]] under head coach [[Jimmy Johnson (American football coach)|Jimmy Johnson]].{{cite book |title=2007 Boston College Football Media Guide |publisher=Boston College Athletics Association |page=80 |chapter=Coaching Staff |url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/bc/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/07guide-3.pdf}} He then spent the next two years as head football coach at [[Hutchinson Community College]], a [[junior college]] in [[Hutchinson, Kansas]]. In his second year there, Logan was named the [[Kansas Jayhawk Community College Conference|Kansas Jayhawk Conference]] Coach of the Year after guiding the team to a 6–4 record.{{cite web |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2199&dat=19830203&id=cdBeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=g-gFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5048,551990 |title=Hutchinson coach Logan hired as Tulsa assistant |author=Associated Press |publisher=[[Lawrence Journal-World]] |accessdate=December 14, 2011}} In 1983, he returned to his [[alma mater]] as an assistant coach for head coach [[John Cooper (American football)|John Cooper]]. While at Tulsa, he tutored the quarterbacks and wide receivers during his first season before taking the reins as [[offensive coordinator]] in 1984. The following year, Logan headed to the [[University of Colorado]] where he coached the Buffaloes' running backs and helped to install the [[Wishbone formation|wishbone]] offense.{{cite web |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZclGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sP0MAAAAIBAJ&pg=5746,1131307&dq=mississippi-state+steve-logan&hl=en |title=State adds another coach |author=Associated Press |date=March 3, 1987 |publisher=[[Gadsden Times]] |accessdate=December 14, 2011}} After two seasons on [[Bill McCartney]]'s staff, he was hired as the quarterbacks coach at [[Mississippi State University]] in 1987. ===East Carolina University=== In 1989, Logan became an assistant coach at [[East Carolina University]]. He was team's offensive coordinator under [[Bill Lewis (football)|Bill Lewis]] from 1990–91, working alongside future Boston College Head Coach [[Jeff Jagodzinski]]. When Logan succeeded Lewis, Jagodzinski remained on staff for four years before accepting the offensive coordinator position at Boston College. The 1991 Pirate team finished 11–1, reached a top-10 national ranking and defeated [[North Carolina State University|NC State]] in the [[Peach Bowl]]. Logan served as the head coach of East Carolina from 1992–2002. He became the school's all-time winning coach (69–58), and led the Pirates to five bowl games, including the 1994 St. Jude [[Liberty Bowl]], the 1995 St. Jude [[Liberty Bowl]], the 1999 [[Mobile Alabama Bowl]], the 2000 [[Galleryfurniture.com Bowl]], and the 2001 [[GMAC Bowl]]. Logan's 1995 team finished with a 9–3 record and a No. 23 ranking in the final Associated Press poll. In 1996, ECU gave the [[Miami Hurricanes]] their worst defeat (31–6) in the [[Miami Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] in 12 seasons. In 1999, ECU upset #9 [[University of Miami|Miami]] at [[Carter-Finley Stadium]] in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]], after [[Hurricane Floyd]] devastated [[Greenville, North Carolina|Greenville]]. For this 9–3 season, which also included victories over [[West Virginia University|West Virginia]], [[University of South Carolina|South Carolina]], and [[North Carolina State University|NC State]] en route to another bowl game. the team won the [[ESPN]] Spirit Award. He resigned on December 7, 2002 after a "substandard" 4–8 season. Three of Logan's quarterbacks; [[Jeff Blake]], [[Marcus Crandell]], and [[David Garrard]] went on to pro careers. ===NFL Europe=== After a one year hiatus from coaching, Logan entered the professional ranks in 2004 with the [[Berlin Thunder]] of [[NFL Europe]], spending two seasons as the team's quarterbacks and wide receivers coach. During his first season, he helped head coach [[Rick Lantz]] lead the Thunder to a 9–1 regular season mark, tying the league record for wins in a season, and a 30–24 victory over the [[Frankfurt Galaxy]] in [[World Bowl XII]].{{cite web |url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/2004-06-12-world-bowl_x.htm |title=Thunder ends NFL Europe season with a bang |last=Kammerer |first=Roy |date=June 12, 2004 |publisher=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=December 22, 2011}} The following year, Berlin again finished the regular season in first place with a record of 7–3,{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/06/08/sports/08iht-BOWL.html |title=World Bowl keeps international flavor |last=Carlson |first=Mike |date=June 9, 2005 |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=December 22, 2011}} but fell to the [[Amsterdam Admirals]] in [[World Bowl XIII]], 27–21.{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/iht/2005/06/12/sports/IHT-12BOWL.html |title=Admirals Surprise in NFL Europe Final |last=Carlson |first=Mike |date=June 12, 2005 |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=December 22, 2011}} In 2006, he served as the offensive coordinator and quarterbacks coach for the [[Rhein Fire]]. Logan helped [[Dave Ragone]] (2004) and [[Rohan Davey]] (2005) earn Offensive Player of the Year and All-NFL Europe honors. ===Boston College=== Logan rejoined former assistant Jeff Jagodzinski as offensive coordinator at Boston College in 2007. He helped develop quarterback [[Matt Ryan (American football)|Matt Ryan]], who would win the ACC Player of the Year, the [[Johnny Unitas Golden Arm Award]], the [[Manning Award]] and was named the AP NFL Rookie of the Year. In January 2009, Jagodzinski got fired after interviewing for the [[New York Jets]] head coaching vacancy.{{cite web |url=http://www.boston.com/sports/colleges/extras/colleges_blog/2009/01/bc_makes_it_off.html|title=BC makes it official: Jagodzinski fired |last=Kilgore |first=Adam |date=January 7, 2009 |work=[[Boston.com]] |publisher=[[The Boston Globe]] |accessdate=December 12, 2011}} Logan was considered a candidate to replace him, and interviewed for the job with Boston College athletic director Gene DeFilippo.{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/sports/colleges/extras/colleges_blog/2009/01/bc_expected_to.html |title=DeFilippo talks to Spaziani, Bicknell, and Logan |last=Blaudschun |first=Mark |date=January 8, 2009 |work=[[Boston.com]] |publisher=[[The Boston Globe]] |accessdate=December 12, 2011}} After the school had promoted defensive coordinator [[Frank Spaziani]] to the head coaching position, Logan decided to leave the program.{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=3838916 |title=Offensive coordinator Logan to leave BC |last=Dinich |first=Heather |date=January 16, 2009 |work=[[ESPN.com]] |accessdate=December 12, 2011}} ===Tampa Bay Buccaneers=== Logan was hired as the running backs coach for the NFL's [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] on February 11, 2009,{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3900440 |title=Bucs add three more coaches |author=Associated Press |date=February 11, 2009 |work=[[ESPN.com]] |accessdate=December 12, 2011}} reuniting him with Jagodzinski, the team's offensive coordinator. After Jagodzinski's firing in September 2009,{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4442178 |title=Just-hired Jagodzinski fired by Bucs |last=Yasinskas |first=Pat |date=September 3, 2009 |work=[[ESPN.com]] |accessdate=December 12, 2011}} Logan remained on the Buccaneers staff. After the Buccaneers 4-12 record in the 2011 season, [[Raheem Morris]] and his entire coaching were fired. ==Personal life== Logan and his wife, Laura, have two sons, Vince and Nate. ==Head coaching record== ===College=== {{CFB Yearly Record Start | type = coach | team = | conf = | bowl = | poll = both }} {{CFB Yearly Record Subhead | name = [[East Carolina Pirates football|East Carolina Pirates]] | conf = [[NCAA Division I FBS independent schools|Independent]] | startyear = 1992 | endyear = 1996 }} {{CFB Yearly Record Entry | championship = | year = [[1992 NCAA Division I-A football
